senses.de: The way a person or animal acts or behaves
senses.ex: His behavior in school was exemplary.

Tips.title: Reflects Personality
Tips.description: Behaviour often gives clues about someone's personality and how they were raised.
Tips.example: His courteous behaviour reflects his respectful upbringing.

Tips.title: Cultural Influence
Tips.description: Behaviour can vary greatly across cultures; what's polite in one may be rude in another.
Tips.example: In Japan, his behaviour of bowing deeply showed respect.

Tips.title: Situation Dependent
Tips.description: The setting, like work or home, greatly influences what behaviour is considered appropriate.
Tips.example: His professional behaviour at the meeting earned him praise.

senses.de: To act or behave in a particular way
senses.ex: The dog is behaving very strangely.

Tips.title: Contextual Reactions
Tips.description: When 'behaviour' is used as a verb, it's about a response to a specific situation.
Tips.example: The cat behaved nervously during the fireworks.

Tips.title: Self-control
Tips.description: 'Behave yourself' is a common instruction to remind someone to act appropriately.
Tips.example: The children were reminded to behave themselves at the wedding.

senses.de: The way in which one acts or conducts oneself, especially towards others
senses.ex: He will vouch for her good behaviour.

Tips.title: Impacts Others
Tips.description: Behaviour in psychology often focuses on how actions affect others socially or emotionally.
Tips.example: Positive behaviour towards classmates promotes a good learning environment.

Tips.title: Consequence Awareness
Tips.description: Understanding the potential rewards or punishments can influence one's behaviour.
Tips.example: He improved his behaviour after discussing the consequences with the counselor.

senses.de: The way in which a natural phenomenon or a machine works or functions
senses.ex: The erratic behaviour of the old car was puzzling to the mechanic.

Tips.title: Non-human Application
Tips.description: 'Behaviour' in physics typically refers to non-living things and how they operate.
Tips.example: Teachers explained the behaviour of gases under different pressures.

Tips.title: Predictive Patterns
Tips.description: Understanding behaviour in physics helps predict and control future occurrences.
Tips.example: Meteorologists study the behaviour of storms to forecast weather.

senses.de: The actions or reactions of a person or an animal in response to external stimuli
senses.ex: The study of animal behaviour provides insights into animal survival strategies.

Tips.title: Instinct vs. Learning
Tips.description: Animal behaviour can be innate or learned, both critical for their survival.
Tips.example: The migratory behaviour of birds is an instinct, guiding them to warmer areas.

Tips.title: Adaptation Significance
Tips.description: Behaviour in biology often changes with the environment, aiding in species adaptation.
Tips.example: Over generations, the behaviour of these animals evolved to avoid predators.

Attitude.wordDefinition:
Attitude refers to a person's thoughts, beliefs, and feelings towards something or someone. It's how they perceive or view things.

Behavior refers to a person's actions or conduct towards something or someone. It's how they react or respond to something based on their attitude.

For example, if someone has a positive attitude towards school, they may believe that education is important and enjoyable.

However, if someone has a negative attitude towards school, they may believe that it's boring or a waste of time. Their behavior may reflect this by skipping class, not paying attention in class, or not completing homework.

Attitude is about thoughts and beliefs, and behavior is about actions and conduct. While attitude can affect behavior, they are two distinct concepts.

Conduct.wordDefinition:
Conduct refers to a person's behavior in relation to ethical, social, and moral standards, it encompasses how they interact with others, their attitudes towards work, and how they handle certain situations.

Behaviour is more about how someone acts in general, while conduct is more about how they act in specific situations or towards specific goals or standards.

For example, a student's behavior in class includes how they interact with their peers and how attentive they are to the teacher, whereas their conduct refers to whether they follow classroom rules and engage in academic integrity.

Behaviour and conduct both relate to how someone acts, but behaviour is broader and conduct is more specific and connected to social and ethical standards.

Demean.wordDefinition:
'Behavior' refers to the way someone conducts themselves or acts in certain situations, while 'demeanor' refers to a person's overall outward behavior or appearance, such as facial expression or posture.

'Behavior' is more specific and applicable to individual actions, whereas 'demeanor' is more general and applies to a person's overall presence.

For example, a person's behavior might be to interrupt others during conversations, while their demeanor may be described as confident or nervous.

Deportment.wordDefinition:
Both words refer to how a person conducts themselves outwardly, but behaviour typically refers to actions while deportment refers to overall mannerisms and posture.

Deportment typically refers to a person's overall mannerisms, such as their posture, facial expressions, and the way they carry themselves.

For example, "her deportment was graceful and elegant."

Overall, behavior is more focused on actions while deportment is focused on mannerisms and presentation.

Disposition.wordDefinition:
Disposition refers to a person's general attitude, mood or temperament. It's the way they tend to feel or react in various situations.

For instance, if someone has a generally optimistic disposition, they might tend to see the positive side of things even when things aren't going well.

Behaviour refers to specific actions or reactions, while disposition is a more general characteristic that influences behaviour.

Etiquette.wordDefinition:
Etiquette refers to the set of rules and customs that govern polite and appropriate behaviour in a particular context or culture.

Etiquette helps us to communicate respect, consideration, and professionalism in our interactions with others.

Behaviour is about our actions and choices, while etiquette is about following specific social norms and rules to communicate respect and appropriateness in different situations.

Mannerism.wordDefinition:
Mannerism refers to a distinctive behavior, gesture, or way of speaking that is specific to an individual.

Behaviour is a general term that describes how someone acts, while mannerism is a specific term that describes the unique way a person behaves.

Temperament.wordDefinition:
Behavior refers to the actions, reactions, and responses that a person shows in certain situations. Temperament refers to a person's innate personality traits that influence their behavior.

Temperament, however, is more consistently a part of a person's personality and is less likely to change.

Both behavior and temperament are applicable in different contexts. For example, behavior is often used in discussions about how people act in social situations, while temperament is often used in discussions about personality traits that are present from birth.

Overall, behavior and temperament are both important to understanding human nature and how people interact with each other in different situations.

quotes.Text: The truth is that we can learn to condition our minds, bodies, and emotions to link pain or pleasure to whatever we choose. By changing what we link pain and pleasure to, we will instantly change our behaviors.
quotes.Title: American Speaker
quotes.Name: Tony Robbins

quotes.Text: I'm just going to say it: I'm pro-guilt. Guilt is good. Guilt helps us stay on track because it's about our behavior. It occurs when we compare something we've done - or failed to do - with our personal values.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Brene Brown

quotes.Text: People say I make strange choices, but they're not strange for me. My sickness is that I'm fascinated by human behavior, by what's underneath the surface, by the worlds inside people.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Johnny Depp

quotes.Text: In acting, I always try to go back to what would actually be the real situation, the real human behavior in life.
quotes.Title: Actor
quotes.Name: Robert De Niro

quotes.Text: When new turns of behavior cease to appear in the life of the individual, its behavior ceases to be intelligent.
quotes.Title: Scottish Philosopher
quotes.Name: Thomas Carlyle

quotes.Text: We must do everything in our power to cease the behaviour that makes children everywhere feel afraid.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Alice Walker

quotes.Text: Character is expressed through our behavior patterns, or natural responses to things.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Joyce Meyer

quotes.Text: You don't buy evil characters lattes. That's not normal behavior.
quotes.Title: British Actor
quotes.Name: Rob James-Collier

quotes.Text: I particularly don't want to play unmotivated behavior.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Michael Zaslow

quotes.Text: Belief that influences behavior influences results.
quotes.Title: American Coach
quotes.Name: Tom Herman
